eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The finite state machine used internally by the button object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ButtonFSM

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed outside with mouse or touch.

eventsFunctions.description: the touch id that is using the button or 0 if none.
eventsFunctions.name: TouchId

eventsBasedObjects.description: A button that can be customized.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelSpriteButton

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: RectangleMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move objects in a rectangular pattern.
description: Move objects in a rectangular pattern with easing functions from the Tween extension.
It can be used for:
- Moveable platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
An example allows to check some settings ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://rectangular-movement)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Entropy
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: AdvancedJump
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Sports and Fitness/Sports and Fitness_training_running_run.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Enhancements for the platformer character: air jump, wall jump wall sliding, coyote time and dashing.
description: This provides behaviors that provide jump enhancements for the platformer character:
* The air jump behavior lets platformer characters jump in mid-air.
* The wall jump behavior lets platformer characters jump and slide against walls.

* The coyote time behavior, also known as "ledge tolerance", lets players to jump even after their character is no longer touching the ground for a given amount of time. It aims to give players a feeling of control and reduce frustration.
* The horizontal dash behavior makes platformer characters dash horizontally.
* The dive dash behavior makes platformer characters dash toward the floor.
An example allows to check it out ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-moves)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Let platformer characters jump shortly after leaving a platform and also jump in mid-air.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: AdvancedJump

events.comment: Avoid any side effect if the feature is not used.
The timeframe is starting.
The timeframe is missed.
Coyote jump
The new value will be used next frame.
While in the coyote jump frame, the Object is treated as being on the floor. No air jump can happen.
When the object fall, it doesn't jump but air jumps must be allowed

The order of these events is important because the idle state is:
on the floor and jump key released but the 1st jump must not count.
Reset air jump counter.
Allow air jumps.
Coyote time was disabled, so WasInTheAir may not have been updated for a long time.

eventsFunctions.description: Change the coyote time duration of an object (in seconds).

events.comment: Coyote time was disabled, so WasInTheAir may not have been updated for a long time.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Let platformer characters jump and slide against walls.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: WallJump

events.comment: Avoid a jump from the floor to do a wall jump because of the allowed timeframe.
Reset default character configuration when a jump that is not a wall jump happens (for instance an air jump).
To know when jumping from the floor or not.
Reset default character configuration when the character change of direction or start to fall.
When the character tries to move but can't actually move, it's against a wall.
Save the previous position for the wall detection.

To be permissive, when the jump key was pressed right before the character touch the wall,
it is still detected as a wall jump which reset the air jump counter.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FireBullet
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading, and overheating.
description: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading, and overheating.
Firing bullets:
- Cooldown: Time between shots (seconds)
- Bullet Quantity: Number of bullets created each time Fire Bullet action is used.
- Angle Variance: Each bullet trajectory will be adjusted by a random value within this range (degrees)
- Firing Arc: Range of angles (in degrees) that bullets will shoot. Bullets are evenly spread within this range.
- Rotate bullet: Change the angle of each bullet to match the direction it is travelling (enabled by default)
Ammo:
- Starting ammo
- Max ammo
- Shots per reload. Use 0 to disable reloading
- Reload duration
- Automatic reloading is enabled by default, but it can also be done manually.
Overheat:
- Heat increase per shot. Object is Overheated when Heat reaches  1.
- Cooling rate per second
- When overheated, the object cannot fire any bullets
Statistics:
- Total bullets created
- Total shots taken
- Total reloads completed
Bullets:
- Each bullet is assigned several variables that can be used for advanced object picking
- __FireBullet.BulletID = Unique number for every bullet created
- __FireBullet.BatchID = Unique number for all bullets created in the same frame
- __FireBullet.BatchOrderID = Unique number for each bullet in the same batch. Can be used to identify the position in the firing arc.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading, and overheating.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: FireBullet

events.comment: Creators can use the "FireBullet" action multiple times in a frame and it will be counted as a single "shot".
Subtract 1 from ammo (if not unlimited ammo)

Detect when reload is completed
Only reload the amount of ammo available

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/) and Entropy (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UClvkb12nOWFgWnQ56NF9Rcw)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ShadowClones
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Create and animate shadow clones that follow the path of a primary object.
description: Select the primary object, the shadow clone object, the number of shadow clones, the number of frames between shadow clones, the rate that shadow clones will reduce opacity and size (if desired), the Z-value and the layer the shadow clones will be created on.
This extension can be used to:
- Make an object look faster, such as during a speed powerup.
- Give a 3D-like feel to a character
- Implement unique time-based elements, like teleporting a character back to a previous location
- Simulate the movement of a caterpillar or slinky
- Recreate games like snake or tron
These object variables are provided to manage the shadow clones:
- ShadowCloneOrder: Shadow clone identifier, where 1 is the shadow clone closest to the primary object
- FramesBehindPrimary: The number of frames that the shadow clone is behind the primary object
Notes:
- For shadow clones to work, this action must be run every frame.
- The ShadowCloneObject cannot be the PrimaryObject, but it can be a duplicate object.
- For animations to work, the PrimaryObject and ShadowCloneObject must use the same animation numbers.
Watch this [tutorial video](https://youtu.be/2t4ANYgrrak) to see examples of how to use this extension.

eventsFunctions.description: Select the primary object, the shadow clone object, the number of shadow clones, the number of frames between shadow clones, the rate that shadow clones will fade away (if desired), the Z-value of the shadow clones, and the layer the shadow clones will be created on.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Animate shadow clones that follow the path of a primary object
eventsFunctions.name: AnimateShadowClones
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create and animate _PARAM3_ copies of _PARAM2_ that follow the position of _PARAM1_, with _PARAM4_ empty frames between shadow clones, and fading the opacity of shadow clones by _PARAM5_ per clone.  Shrink scale of shadow clones by _PARAM6_ per clone. Shadow clones will be created on _PARAM7_ layer with a Z-value of _PARAM8_.  Match X scale: _PARAM9_  Match Y scale: _PARAM10_  Match angle: _PARAM11_  Match animation: _PARAM12_  Match animation frame: _PARAM13_

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: westboy31, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake layer cameras with translation, rotation and zoom.
description: Shake layer cameras with translation, rotation and zoom.
- Short shaking can be used to give impact (explosion, hit)
- Shaking can go indefinitely to set an ambiance (engine vibration, earthquake, pulsing)
- Low frequency shaking allows to simulate slow moving objects (ship rocking back and forth)
- Setting amplitudes per layer make it possible to respect the parallax and give more depth
Release notes:
- Version 3.0.0
- No adaptation of the game events is needed.
- It fixes an issue when used with scrolling, the amplitude will feel bigger in this case.
- The shaking relies on noise which could feel a bit different.
- This extension can no longer do impulses. For this, another extension "Camera impulse" can be used.

events.comment: Step time counters.
Use user defined default values when there is no layer specific value set.

Shake the layer camera.
Save the camera displacement to revert it in onScenePostEvents.
Revert the shaking.

eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera for _PARAM1_ seconds with _PARAM2_ seconds of easing to start and _PARAM3_ seconds to stop

eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera on _PARAM3_ layer for _PARAM5_ seconds. Use an amplitude of _PARAM1_px on X axis and _PARAM2_px on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM6_ degrees, and zoom amplitude _PARAM7_ percent.  Wait _PARAM8_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM9_

Add default values if none were provided

inlineCode: * Create the manager of noise generators.
* Create a noise generator with a seed.
// Make the circle perimeter equals to the looping period
// to keep the same perceived frequency with or without looping.
noiseSum += noiseFunction(x * frequency, y * frequency, z * frequency, w * frequency) * amplitude;
A fast javascript implementation of simplex noise by Jonas Wagner
Based on a speed-improved simplex noise algorithm for 2D, 3D and 4D in Java.
Which is based on example code by Stefan Gustavson (stegu@itn.liu.se).
Better rank ordering method by Stefan Gustavson in 2012.

of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal

/** Deterministic simplex noise generator suitable for 2D, 3D and 4D spaces. */
* This involves some setup. You can save a few cpu cycles by reusing the same instance.
* @param {(() => number)|string|number} randomOrSeed A random number generator or a seed (string|number).
const random = typeof randomOrSeed == 'function' ? randomOrSeed : alea(randomOrSeed);
* Samples the noise field in 2 dimensions
let n0 = 0; // Noise contributions from the three corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y) * F2; // Hairy factor for 2D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y distances from the cell origin
// For the 2D case, the simplex shape is an equilateral triangle.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1; // Offsets for second (middle) corner of simplex in (i,j) coords
// A step of (1,0) in (i,j) means a step of (1-c,-c) in (x,y), and
// a step of (0,1) in (i,j) means a step of (-c,1-c) in (x,y), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G2; // Offsets for middle corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
const x2 = x0 - 1.0 + 2.0 * G2; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the three simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the three corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0); // (x,y) of grad3 used for 2D gradient
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1);
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to return values in the interval [-1,1].
* Samples the noise field in 3 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3; // Noise contributions from the four corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y + z) * F3; // Very nice and simple skew factor for 3D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z distances from the cell origin
// For the 3D case, the simplex shape is a slightly irregular tetrahedron.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1, k1; // Offsets for second corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
let i2, j2, k2; // Offsets for third corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
// A step of (1,0,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (1-c,-c,-c) in (x,y,z),
// a step of (0,1,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,1-c,-c) in (x,y,z), and
// a step of (0,0,1) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,-c,1-c) in (x,y,z), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G3; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G3; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x3 = x0 - 1.0 + 3.0 * G3; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the four simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the four corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad3[gi0 + 2] * z0);
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1]]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad3[gi1 + 2] * z1);
const gi2 = permMod12[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2]]] * 3;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad3[gi2 + 2] * z2);
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad3[gi3] * x3 + grad3[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad3[gi3 + 2] * z3);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to stay just inside [-1,1]
* Samples the noise field in 4 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3, n4; // Noise contributions from the five corners
// Skew the (x,y,z,w) space to determine which cell of 24 simplices we're in
const s = (x + y + z + w) * F4; // Factor for 4D skewing
const t = (i + j + k + l) * G4; // Factor for 4D unskewing
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z,w) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z,w distances from the cell origin
// For the 4D case, the simplex is a 4D shape I won't even try to describe.
// To find out which of the 24 possible simplices we're in, we need to
// determine the magnitude ordering of x0, y0, z0 and w0.
// Six pair-wise comparisons are performed between each possible pair
// of the four coordinates, and the results are used to rank the numbers.
// simplex[c] is a 4-vector with the numbers 0, 1, 2 and 3 in some order.
// Many values of c will never occur, since e.g. x>y>z>w makes x<z, y<w and x<w
// impossible. Only the 24 indices which have non-zero entries make any sense.
// We use a thresholding to set the coordinates in turn from the largest magnitude.
// Rank 2 denotes the second largest coordinate.
// Rank 1 denotes the second smallest coordinate.
// The integer offsets for the second simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the third simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the fourth simplex corner
// The fifth corner has all coordinate offsets = 1, so no need to compute that.
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G4; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G4; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x3 = x0 - i3 + 3.0 * G4; // Offsets for fourth corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x4 = x0 - 1.0 + 4.0 * G4; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the five simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the five corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad4[gi0] * x0 + grad4[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad4[gi0 + 2] * z0 + grad4[gi0 + 3] * w0);
const gi1 = (perm[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1 + perm[ll + l1]]]] % 32) * 4;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad4[gi1] * x1 + grad4[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad4[gi1 + 2] * z1 + grad4[gi1 + 3] * w1);
const gi2 = (perm[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2 + perm[ll + l2]]]] % 32) * 4;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad4[gi2] * x2 + grad4[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad4[gi2 + 2] * z2 + grad4[gi2 + 3] * w2);
const gi3 = (perm[ii + i3 + perm[jj + j3 + perm[kk + k3 + perm[ll + l3]]]] % 32) * 4;
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad4[gi3] * x3 + grad4[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad4[gi3 + 2] * z3 + grad4[gi3 + 3] * w3);
n4 = t4 * t4 * (grad4[gi4] * x4 + grad4[gi4 + 1] * y4 + grad4[gi4 + 2] * z4 + grad4[gi4 + 3] * w4);
// Sum up and scale the result to cover the range [-1,1]
* This is exported only for (internal) testing purposes.
* Do not rely on this export.
The ALEA PRNG and masher code used by simplex-noise.js
is based on code by Johannes Baagøe, modified by Jonas Wagner.
See alea.md for the full license.

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a number from 2 dimensional simplex noise.
eventsFunctions.name: Noise2d

eventsFunctions.description: Create a noise generator with default settings (frequency = 1,  octaves = 1, persistence = 0.5, lacunarity = 2).
eventsFunctions.name: Create

eventsFunctions.description: Delete a noise generator and loose its settings.
eventsFunctions.name: Delete

eventsFunctions.description: Delete all noise generators and loose their settings.
eventsFunctions.name: DeleteAll

eventsFunctions.description: The seed is a number used to generate the random noise. Setting the same seed will result in the same random noise generation. It's for example useful to generate the same world, by saving this seed value and reusing it later to generate again a world.
eventsFunctions.name: SetSeed

eventsFunctions.description: Change the looping period on X used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on X.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLoopPeriodX
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the looping period on X of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the looping period on Y used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on Y.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLoopPeriodY
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the looping period on Y of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the base frequency used for noise generation. A lower frequency will zoom in the noise.
eventsFunctions.name: SetFrequency

eventsFunctions.description: Change the number of octaves used for noise generation. It can be seen as layers of noise with different zoom.
eventsFunctions.name: SetOctaves
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the number of noise octaves of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the persistence used for noise generation. At its default value "0.5", it halves the noise amplitude at each octave.
eventsFunctions.name: SetPersistence

eventsFunctions.description: Change the lacunarity used for noise generation. At its default value "2", it doubles the frequency at each octave.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLacunarity

eventsFunctions.name: Octaves

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ShakeObject
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, scale).
description: Select one or more methods of shaking:
- Position: Shake the X and/or Y position of the object
- Angle: Shake the angle (rotation) of the object
- Scale: Shake the scale of the object (must be a sprite)
Control how the object shakes:
- Amplitude: How far the object moves during each shake
- Duration: Amount of time to shake the object
- Time between shakes: Amount of time between each movement of the object
- Keep shaking until stopped (boolean)
Tips:
- For a single-shake effect, set the "Time between shakes" to be equal to "Duration"  (great for a hit or impact)
- To make the single-shake move in the opposite direction, use negative numbers
- To repeat a single-shake effect in a loop, add a condition "Object is not shaking"
- Use a long "Time between shakes" to simulate a slow moving object (like a ship rocking back and forth)
- Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters.
- Use "Shake until stopped" to simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle).
This behavior can be used on any type of object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle

eventsFunctions.description: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle).
eventsFunctions.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake object _PARAM0_ for _PARAM2_ seconds. Modify position amplitude _PARAM3_ on X axis and _PARAM4_ on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM5_.  Wait _PARAM6_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM7_

Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake
Detect initial shake
Initiate the onScenePostEvents function

Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Save that initial shake has been processed

Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)

This behavior can only be used on sprite objects.

events.comment: Start/Reset duration timer

events.comment: Keep object shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Calculate Scale shake
Calculate object scale displacement, with linear decay over time
ScaleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100
Every even shake, increase scale
Every "odd" shake, decrease scale
ScaleDisplacement = -1 * (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100
